title: Chem-FINESE: Validating Fine-Grained Few-shot Entity Extraction through Text Reconstruction. (arXiv:2401.10189v1 [cs.CL])
abstract: Fine-grained few-shot entity extraction in the chemical domain faces two unique challenges. First, compared with entity extraction tasks in the general domain, sentences from chemical papers usually contain more entities. Moreover, entity extraction models usually have difficulty extracting entities of long-tailed types. In this paper, we propose Chem-FINESE, a novel sequence-to-sequence (seq2seq) based few-shot entity extraction approach, to address these two challenges. Our Chem-FINESE has two components: a seq2seq entity extractor to extract named entities from the input sentence and a seq2seq self-validation module to reconstruct the original input sentence from extracted entities. Inspired by the fact that a good entity extraction system needs to extract entities faithfully, our new self-validation module leverages entity extraction results to reconstruct the original input sentence. Besides, we design a new contrastive loss to reduce excessive copying during the extraction proces

translated_title: Chem-FINESE: 通过文本重构验证细粒度少样本实体提取
translated_abstract: 在化学领域中，细粒度少样本实体提取面临两个独特的挑战。首先，与一般领域的实体提取任务相比，化学论文中的句子通常包含更多的实体。此外，实体提取模型通常难以提取长尾类型的实体。在本文中，我们提出了一种新颖的基于序列到序列的少样本实体提取方法Chem-FINESE来解决这两个挑战。我们的Chem-FINESE包含两个组件：一个序列到序列的实体提取器用于从输入句子中提取命名实体，以及一个序列到序列的自我验证模块用于从提取的实体中重构原始输入句子。受到一个好的实体提取系统需要忠实提取实体的事实启发，我们的新自我验证模块利用实体提取结果来重构原始输入句子。此外，我们设计了一种新的对比损失来减少在提取过程中的过度复制。
tldr: 这篇论文提出了一种名为Chem-FINESE的方法来处理化学领域中细粒度少样本实体提取的问题。该方法通过使用序列到序列的实体提取器和自我验证模块来从输入句子中提取命名实体并重构原始输入句子。实验证明了该方法的有效性和可行性。
en_tdlr: This paper proposes a method called Chem-FINESE to address the challenge of fine-grained few-shot entity extraction in the chemical domain. The method uses a sequence-to-sequence entity extractor and a self-validation module to extract named entities from input sentences and reconstruct the original sentences. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed method.
